How do you honor the legacy of a woman who helped REVOLUTIONIZE medicine?

As a Congressman from a historic district seaport boasting numerous small harbors, this is big news. It opens up new funding that will prevent coastal flooding and protect jobs. As always, I will fight to protect the fishing traditions of the MA-06 💪

Yesterday, the House passed this year’s Water Resource Development Act (WRDA), a victory for our nation’s water infrastructure. This year, following a letter I led to House leadership, funds set aside for protecting our small harbors were increased from 10% to 15%.

“I cry every day when I walk in to work, and I cry every day when I walk to my car after work.”

We owe it to the heroes putting their lives on the line to do all we can to stop the spread of this virus. 

https://www.washingtonpost.com/graphics/2020/national/icu-nurses-covid-19/

If Congress passes this bill, even by the most conservative estimates, it will put 2.6 million Americans to work in a time when we desperately need more jobs. We can transform our communities and commutes if we come together and go big.

We spend vast amounts of money subsidizing planes, which are delayed by weather, and roads, which are crumbling nationwide. We have the chance coming out of this pandemic to think big and think differently. Let’s not waste the opportunity.

High-speed rail is faster, cleaner, safer and better for our economy. It will connect people to more jobs in new places, give Americans freedom and choice in how they travel, and put us on par with the rest of the world. This bill is the plan that will get us there.
Today I unveiled my American High-Speed Rail Act with @RepDelBene and @CongBoyle.

RT @yhn .@RepByrne in farewell address to Congress, says he has ‘hope and optimism’ about the future of America 
By @HenryThornton95 https://yellowhammernews.com/byrne-in-farewell-address-to-congress-says-he-has-hope-and-optimism-about-the-future-of-america/

I want to thank my long suffering family. They loved me and they supported me, even when I wasn’t so lovable, and even when it wasn’t so easy to support me. I could not have done it without them and so many others. Thank you for allowing me to serve, and may God bless America!

Division in our country is the greatest internal threat we’ve got, because there is nothing that this great nation can’t accomplish when we are united, when we are "e pluribus unum" -- one out of many. That is who America is, and that’s who the American people want us to be.

Many say this country is in a bad place and headed in the wrong direction. I believe that view ignores two very important things: our history, and what the people of America have been telling us. If Americans knew their history better, they would be more hopeful and optimistic.

It has been an honor to serve the people of Southwest Alabama in Washington these past seven years. As I bid my farewell to the House, I leave with a feeling of hope and optimism that God will continue to bless our great nation. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ziXMkIKQXA&t=2s

RT @RepJerryNadler The Consumer Bankruptcy Reform Act works for American families by cracking down on predatory practices, helping renters avoid eviction, making student loan debt dischargeable in bankruptcy, and more. I'm proud to partner with @SenWarren on this bill that puts consumers first. https://twitter.com/SenWarren/status/1336689019279781889 QT @SenWarren As a law professor, I found that most bankruptcies are from an illness, job loss, or family death/breakup. COVID is pushing families over a financial cliff, and our system isn't providing relief. So @RepJerryNadler and I have a new bill to #FixBankruptcy. https://www.warren.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/warren-and-nadler-introduce-the-consumer-bankruptcy-reform-act-of-2020 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EozbLyFXcAE-81P.png

I’ve sat in bankruptcy courtrooms and heard the stories of people who worked hard, had big dreams, and whose lives took a terrible turn. Bankruptcy is supposed to be a last resort to help people pull themselves back up. We must #FixBankruptcy to give people a fighting chance.

Even before the pandemic hit, Americans were already hanging on by their fingernails. In the last 40 years, consumer credit skyrocketed. People took on more debt to deal with stagnant wages and increasing costs of housing, education, medical care, and child care. #FixBankruptcy

It’s time to stitch up the loopholes that allow the wealthy to exploit the bankruptcy system. And we need to crack down on predatory debt collection practices and hold corporate wrongdoers accountable in court. #FixBankruptcy

We also need to address racial and gender disparities in the bankruptcy system. That includes letting people discharge certain criminal justice fines but preventing the discharge of debts from civil rights violations, and exempting alimony and child support income. #FixBankruptcy

Our bill helps bankruptcy filers care for their families by helping renters with back rent avoid eviction, making student loan debt dischargeable, and letting people protect their homes and cars during the bankruptcy process. #FixBankruptcy

Our Consumer Bankruptcy Reform Act simplifies and modernizes the consumer bankruptcy system to help people struggling with debt – starting by creating a single system for all consumers, streamlining the filing process, and reducing filing fees. #FixBankruptcy

As a law professor, I found that most bankruptcies are from an illness, job loss, or family death/breakup. COVID is pushing families over a financial cliff, and our system isn't providing relief. So @RepJerryNadler and I have a new bill to #FixBankruptcy. https://www.warren.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/warren-and-nadler-introduce-the-consumer-bankruptcy-reform-act-of-2020 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EozbLyFXcAE-81P.png

More competition means more options for consumers and content creators, and more pressure on companies like Facebook to address the glaring problems with their businesses. Healthy competition can solve a lot of problems and it’s how we can protect the future of the Internet.

I want a government that makes sure everybody—even the biggest and most powerful companies in America—plays by the rules. And I want to make sure that the next generation of great American tech companies can flourish.

And they’ve wielded that power over everything—over our economy, our society, and our democracy. They’ve bulldozed competition, used our private information for profit, and tilted the playing field. And in the process, they have hurt small businesses and stifled innovation.

Facebook is doing pretty well right now. They've acquired potential competitors WhatsApp and Instagram. More than 85% of all social networking traffic goes through sites owned or operated by Facebook. They've got a lot of power—and face little competition or accountability.

For nearly two years now, I’ve been calling to #BreakUpBigTech—including Facebook. I’d said before that the purchases of WhatsApp and Instagram should never have been approved and need to be reversed. Today, the FTC and 48 states agreed. 

https://www.politico.com/news/2020/12/09/states-ftc-suing-facebook-for-alleged-antitrust-abuses-443957

Bankruptcy laws affect Americans when they need it most. I’ll be fighting to make this plan a reality because government should be on the side of the people—but I can’t do it alone. We need to raise our voices as a grassroots movement.

It will also help address shameful racial and gender disparities in bankruptcy. Families of color have far less wealth than white families on average, and far more debt. And to make matters worse, families of color are far more likely to be abused by predatory lending practices.

My bill will make it easier for people being crushed by debt to get relief, end the absurd loopholes that make it impossible to discharge student loan debt in bankruptcy, close loopholes that allow the wealthy and corporate creditors to abuse bankruptcy, and more.

But right now, our bankruptcy system isn't working for working families. Many individuals and families who should file for bankruptcy don't, and many who do encounter obstacles that prevent them from getting the financial relief they need.

Data show that families who declare bankruptcy aren’t reckless or irresponsible—90% declare bankruptcy for one of three reasons: a job loss, a medical problem, or a family breakup. This has been a problem for decades, and the pandemic will likely make it worse.

Here’s a lingering effect COVID-19 will likely have on our economy: a rise in bankruptcies. The number of people filing for bankruptcy could hit records next year. Let’s talk about how my bill to overhaul consumer bankruptcy rules will help Americans get back on their feet: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eo0MfV4XIAED9ct.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1336738108373676032/vid/320x320/9zy6wHFxLOc_o-vo.mp4?tag=13

We don’t have to do this. We don’t have to let this crisis keep kicking families in the teeth. We can make sure people get meaningful relief—and we must.

I really want everyone to understand why this is so important. State, local, and Tribal gov'ts are on the frontlines of this pandemic—& in order for them to continue their work & protect their communities, they desperately need the federal support that Dems are fighting for.

If state, local, and Tribal gov'ts don't have money, some of those jobs—& services—will be cut. This will impact trash collection, the number of educators at schools, communities' ability to do COVID-19 testing, contract tracing, & vaccine preparation, and more.

State, local, and Tribal governments are responsible for employing everything from firefighters and EMTs to sanitary workers and public works departments. Educators and law enforcement, as well as public health workers, all fall into this category.

I want to share with you all why Dems are fighting so hard to make sure state, local, & Tribal gov'ts get the support they need.

Today I spoke on the floor the urge the Senate to block the U.S. arms sales to the UAE. We should NOT be contributing to an arms race in the Middle East. I’ve said it before and I’ll say it again. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QM47lxsTYCQ&feature=youtu.be
I urge my colleagues to consider the possible consequences of this sale. We should not accelerate an arms race in the Middle East. I urge a vote in support of these resolutions of disapproval.
The answers to these questions are far from clear. In fact, the UAE’s record should give us pause.

• What military behavior are we encouraging and rewarding with this sale? 

• Will the U.S. bear responsibility if the UAE misuses these incredibly sophisticated weapons?

The primary questions we should be asking ourselves:

• To what ends has the UAE deployed its military—and its military technology—in recent years?

• Does the UAE have a record that we can trust?

The buyer of all this military technology is the United Arab Emirates, a country that has recently taken encouraging steps—specifically towards Israel—but with an overall record that should give concern.
The Senate is debating, with these joint resolutions, whether to disapprove of the announced sale of 50 F-35s, 18 Reaper Drones, as well as missiles and other related equipment.

I'm speaking on the floor in support of two bipartisan joint resolutions of disapproval blocking a UAE arms sale. Someone must ask the question: Can a lasting peace be purchased with more weapons? Watch here: https://www.c-span.org/congress/?chamber=senate

To access rental assistance resources, I encourage tenants, non-profits, and landlords to visit http://mohousingresources.com.
 
As we move into winter, we must take advantage of all available funding to keep roofs over the heads of our neighbors.

Between the two programs, our state has nearly $30 million set aside to keep people in their homes. 
 
But in order for these programs to work, non-profits and landlords must apply for these funds, and renters must be made aware of available assistance.

Right now, $13.3 million from the Missouri Housing Development Commission is already available to non-profit agencies involved in homelessness prevention.
 
Later this week, another $15 million will be made available by the MHDC through the Rental Arrears Program.

The CDC’s eviction moratorium is set to expire on December 31.
 
If we’re going to avoid an eviction tsunami, we need all hands on deck.
 
That’s why I’m calling on non-profits and landlords to mobilize all available CARES Act funding to prevent evictions.

One of the goals of the Social Capital Project is straightforward: “We want more children in happy married-parent families.” Recognizing the social and economic barriers that cause more couples to put off marriage should be a priority for policymakers.

"Surprisingly, the women who did not marry continued having children at a similar rate. As a result, nonmarital births in that population soared. Today, 54% of moderately educated women and 66 % of those with a high school diploma or less are unmarried mothers."

Despite these gains, women are having more trouble finding a desirable husband or partner: "In 1960, more than 90% of adult women over 35 had married.
As of 2015, 71% of college educated women were married; that was true for only 56% of less educated women."
@ManhattanInst's @KayHymowitz points out that for the last quarter of 2019, women held the majority of nonfarm payroll positions. "Something that could be said of no other OECD country."

"In the past, women who worked almost always left the labor force when they gave birth. Today working motherhood is the new normal. 
As of 2017, 71.3% of mothers of children under 18 were in the labor force." @KayHymowitz http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ERu_9q-WAAEOJFf.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1232719802671779842/vid/480x270/T4cZWB5gFYl2r7qX.mp4?tag=13

When asked what is essential to a fulfilling life, the top three were:
1️⃣ making a good living
2️⃣ gaining a good education
3️⃣ having a rewarding career 
While the majority agrees that marriage is beneficial, they don't necessarily view it as a priority for a fulfilling life.

Despite generally positive views of the benefits of marriage, however, it did not rank highly in terms of what is essential to a fulfilling life. It ranked second to last, with only “having children” ranking below it.
When asked about the ideal sequence of relationships and childbearing, respondents overall said that childbearing should take place after marriage.

64% of respondents agreed that marriage makes people better off financially; 59% agreed that marriage is necessary to create strong families; 53% agreed that society is better off when more people are married; and only 14% agreed that marriage is more of a burden than a benefit. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eozgv1EXYAYmhqk.jpg

JUST IN: Watch Subcommittee Chair @RepRaskin question officials about FERC’s role in protecting the property rights of landowners against overreaching abuses of eminent domain by natural gas companies. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eo0D-K5XYAYRRh1.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1336726502168260612/vid/432x270/jtDG6vyrUZX4rHdM.mp4?tag=13

“[There] is no excuse for running roughshod over individual rights.  The process of regulating the construction of natural gas pipelines needs to be balanced.  Congress designed it to be so.  It’s time we make that design reality.” — @RepRaskin

“In contrast, over that same period, FERC didn’t approve a single landowner appeal.  A system where corporations win nearly 100% of the time and people win 0% of the time is inherently suspect and reeks of injustice.”

“In every way we have examined, FERC is biased against individual landowners.
Here’s one example of FERC’s bias. In the last 20 years, FERC has received 1,021 applications for natural gas projects. It has only denied six. That is higher than a 99% approval rate.”

“FERC is supposed to protect the people.

But our Subcommittee’s investigation has found that, rather than acting as a crucial check on energy companies, FERC has been a rubber stamp for the energy companies that build pipelines on their land.”

Subcommittee Chair @RepRaskin strongly implored @FERC to put the public interest over corporate interest as he opened today’s hearing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wzN6iAJ6YCo&feature=youtu.be

“Well, we are answering that call today, and I hope my colleagues on both sides of the aisle will join Chairman Raskin in his fight to restore balance and fairness to the FERC pipeline process.” — @RepMaloney

“‘I’m as conservative as they come. The Republican Party was built on private property rights….this is one of our core issues.’

He called on Republicans to stand up for the little guy—for the folks in poor rural counties who may not have the resources to fight big pipelines.”

“Bill Gow is a landowner in Douglas County, Oregon in the pathway of the Jordan Cove project. 

Describing his opposition to big pipeline companies and the FERC process, Mr. Gow said, ‘I have been a Republican for 45 years.’”

“The [Subcommittee’s] investigation revealed that FERC has a near-100% approval rate for pipelines. At the same time, however, FERC denied every single landowner appeal over the last twelve years…

...This issue presents an excellent opportunity for bipartisanship.”

Chair @RepMaloney opened today’s hearing with a call for bipartisan action to hold @FERC accountable for prioritizing the interests of pipeline companies over the rights of landowners.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OZCUfeUAZtI&feature=youtu.be

MCCONNELL: I suggested that both sides drop what seems to be the most controversial demand in the eyes of our counterparts. Negotiating 101 suggests we set them aside and plow ahead where we can. But that would require both sides to truly want an outcome.

MCCONNELL: I said leading Democrats simply didn’t want any more help to reach American families before the election. 

Democrats claimed great offense: How insulting to even suggest that much cynicism might be at play.

But now they’re admitting it. Out loud.

MCCONNELL: The Speaker of the House views it as a success that she denied struggling people relief they badly needed for months because she thinks she got the political result she was after.

MCCONNELL: Senate Republicans have made one offer after another to try and make law on all the significant areas where nobody even disagrees. We have spent July, Aug., Sept., Oct., and Nov. trying different ways to create common ground. But they delay and block those efforts.

MCCONNELL: Americans who’ve been thrown out of work through no fault of their own are watching federal aid programs tick toward expiration in a few weeks because Democrats who don't even oppose extending them have blocked them repeatedly.

MCCONNELL: Medically-vulnerable Americans have watched Operation Warp Speed succeeding at an historic pace, only to find that Democrats can’t even agree to fully fund the distribution efforts that will get the vaccine to them.

MCCONNELL: Small-business employees who’ve held onto their job all this time because of the Paycheck Protection Program are facing the prospect they might be laid off now -- with vaccines around the corner -- because Washington Democrats are fumbling the ball in the red zone.

MCCONNELL: The American people are hurting. We’re in the thick of one of the worst national crises in modern memory. And people’s eyes are fixed on Congress. They need the House and the Senate to stop chasing our tails and make law.
